questions.text:
A 66-year-old nonbinary individual presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath with exertion. The patient reports increasing shortness of breath over the past several weeks to the point where they can no longer climb a flight of stairs without becoming winded. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and deep vein thrombosis following a knee replacement surgery ten years ago. The patient has not seen a physician in years and is currently not on any medications. They currently smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 188/92 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 91% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional heart sound heard just after S2, and diffuse rales on lung auscultation. Jugular venous distension, pitting edema, and hepatomegaly are absent. A chest X-ray is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s pulmonary findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with left-heart failure including an S3 gallop and pulmonary edema. The primary pathophysiology underlying pulmonary edema secondary to left-sided heart failure is an increase in pulmonary venous pressure and subsequent transudation of fluid into the lung parenchyma.  

Left-sided heart failure refers to anatomical failure of the left-side of the heart only and presents with characteristic symptoms and examination findings. Notably, patients present with orthopnea (shortness of breath when lying supine), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (breathless awakening from sleep), and pulmonary edema. The former two findings are largely due to increased venous return and redistribution of blood when lying flat, whereas pulmonary edema results from impaired forward arterial blood flow and vascular congestion.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased pulmonary venous pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased pulmonary venous pressure :
Incorrect: Increased, not decreased, pulmonary venous pressure likely underlies this patient’s pulmonary findings. With left-sided heart failure, poor ejection fraction manifests with increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and subsequent transudation of fluid into the lung parenchyma.
❌ Increased central venous pressure :
Incorrect: Increased central venous pressure occurs in the setting of right heart failure. Right heart failure can manifest with pitting edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and jugular venous distension. In contrast, these findings are absent in this patient. 
❌ Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure:
Incorrect: Increased, not decreased, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure leads to the development of pulmonary edema.   
❌ Recurrent pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of a remote deep vein thrombosis, he has no evidence of right heart failure on examination. This patient’s pulmonary findings are more likely secondary to left-sided heart failure and a different underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a three week history of worsening fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and lower extremity swelling. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but notes no recent travel, sick contacts, or illnesses. She recalls one episode of nausea and diaphoresis while she was lifting boxes at home approximately one month ago, but she does not recall any chest pain or shortness of breath at that time. She is a life-time non-smoker and reports drinking one glass of wine every night with dinner. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9° F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities and prominent jugular veins. An additional heart sound is heard just after S2, and faint bibasilar crackles are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrates a dilated left ventricle and increased end-diastolic volume, and wall motion abnormalities are noted along the anterolateral heart border. Ejection fraction by visualization is estimated at 34%. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Infection with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus

questions.solution:
Systolic heart failure is most commonly due to ischemia or myocardial infarction, which causes decreased cardiac contractility that leads to systolic dysfunction. The inability of the heart to effectively pump blood forward through circulation results in clinical features of left-sided heart failure causing pulmonary edema: fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, as well as bibasilar crackles and an S3 heart sound (ventricular gallop) on examination. This often progresses to right-sided heart failure, resulting in jugular venous distention (JVD), pitting edema, and hepatic congestion. The patient in this question likely suffered an atypical or silent myocardial infarction while she was moving boxes several weeks ago, and without appropriate treatment, she has now developed systolic heart failure. Other causes of systolic heart failure include etiologies of dilated cardiomyopathy including alcohol, coxsackie B virus infection, chronic cocaine use, or Chagas disease. Echocardiography typically shows an increased end diastolic volume (EDV), decreased contractility (or wall motion abnormalities), and reduced ejection fraction (EF).

In contrast to systolic heart failure, diastolic heart failure is most commonly due to cardiac hypertrophy from long-standing, untreated hypertension. It presents with the same clinical features as systolic heart failure. Echocardiographic findings generally demonstrate a preserved EF and a normal EDV. Patients with diastolic heart failure will also have decreased compliance (increased end diastolic pressure) due to stiff ventricular walls. Other etiologies of diastolic heart failure include infiltrative diseases such as amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, or post-radiation fibrosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Long-standing untreated hypertension:
Incorrect: Long standing untreated hypertension typically results in findings of diastolic heart failure due to concentric hypertrophy. Findings include a preserved ejection fraction and a normal end-diastolic volume. The patient in this vignette has an increased end diastolic volume and a reduced ejection fraction making an etiology of systolic heart failure more likely.
✅ Ischemic heart disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repetitive vasoconstriction of pulmonary vasculature:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of chronic smoking and COPD leading to cor pulmonale or isolated right sided heart failure. Prolonged vasoconstriction of pulmonary vasculature increases demand on the right heart, eventually leading to peripheral edema and hepatic congestion without pulmonary edema. The patient in this vignette has findings of pulmonary edema and is not a smoker, making this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Alcohol can cause dilated cardiomyopathy and systolic heart failure; however, this occurs only with heavy consumption. The patient in this vignette is described as consuming within the recommended drink limit per day, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Infection with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: This question stem describes the pathophysiology of a dilated cardiomyopathy from coxsackie B virus, which can cause systolic heart failure (as seen in this patient). This answer choice is less likely in this patient without a recent history of infectious illness.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old male presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and fatigue. He is found to be critically ill and is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation and monitoring. While in the ICU, the patient has a Swan-Ganz catheter placed in the right heart for continuous hemodynamic measurements. An initial set of readings is demonstrated below:


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative rod
Hemorrhage due to bleeding peptic ulcer

questions.solution:
This critically ill patient had a Swan-Ganz catheter placed and hemodynamic measurements taken. The findings include a decreased cardiac output (of which the cardiac index is a surrogate measure taking into account BMI), increased systemic vascular resistance, increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2). These parameters are consistent with cardiogenic shock, of which heart failure is a common etiology.  

A Swan-Ganz catheter is a flexible tube passed into the right side of the heart and the pulmonary artery. It is used to take measurements of cardiac output (heart x stroke volume), systemic vascular resistance (80x (Mean Arterial Pressure - Mean Venous Pressure or CVP) / Cardiac Output), PCWP (surrogate of left atrial pressure), and SvO2 (measure of total body oxygen consumption). While seldom used in modern ICUs, it was historically used to provide useful information in determining the etiology of a patient’s shock.  


Option Analysis

✅ Heart failure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative rod:
Incorrect: Septic shock is a subtype of distributive shock that presents with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, increased cardiac output, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation. This patient’s findings are inconsistent with those of septic shock.
❌ Impaired sympathetic outflow:
Incorrect: Neurogenic shock is another subtype of distributive shock that presents with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, decreased cardiac output, and an increased mixed venous oxygen saturation. It is most commonly caused by spinal cord injury that disrupts sympathetic outflow. In contrast, this patient has an elevated systemic vascular resistance.
❌ Thrombus in the pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Obstructive shock is a subtype of “cold shock” and can be caused by pulmonary embolism. It can present with increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased cardiac output, and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation. In causes of obstructive shock secondary to pulmonary embolism, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (surrogate of left atrial pressure) is reduced since less blood is reaching the left heart.
❌ Hemorrhage due to bleeding peptic ulcer:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic shock presents with increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, decreased cardiac output, and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation. It is most commonly due to ongoing hemorrhage from trauma or gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. She currently lives in a rehabilitation facility, where she is undergoing rehabilitation after having a total hip replacement. Past medical history is notable for COPD, type II diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 84/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 76% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is in respiratory distress with clammy and cool extremities. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for jugular venous distension but is otherwise unremarkable. ECG is demonstrated below:

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators
Occlusion of the right coronary artery

questions.solution:
This patient has profound hypotension, hypoxemia, and cool clammy extremities in the setting of a recent surgery and prolonged immobilization. Her overall clinical presentation is consistent with a massive pulmonary embolism resulting in obstructive shock and ventilation perfusion mismatch. Her presentation warrants consideration for treatment with thrombolytic therapy, which will break down the thrombus.  

Obstructive shock described impaired end-organ perfusion due to physical obstruction of circulation either into or out of the heart. It falls under the umbrella of “cold shock”, which manifests with clammy and cool extremities due to decreased cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance to shunt blood towards vital organs.  

There are three primary causes of obstructive shock: pulmonary embolism, pericardial tamponade, and tension pneumothorax. A pulmonary embolism manifests with obstructive shock due to the right heart's inability to pump blood through the pulmonary vasculature, causing profound V/Q mismatch, jugular venous distension, hypoxemia, and compromised left ventricular cardiac output. Pericardial tamponade refers to accumulation of blood or fluid in the pericardial sac, of which there are numerous causes including trauma, uremia, and pericarditis. When the amount of pericardial fluid reaches a critical threshold, ventricular filling and outflow becomes compromised, warranting pericardiocentesis. Lastly, a tension pneumothorax results in compression of mediastinal structures and causes decreased venous return and stroke volume. Treatment involves rapid decompression with needle thoracostomy followed by chest tube placement.



Option Analysis

✅ V/Q mismatch:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased venous return:
Incorrect: Hypovolemic shock is associated with decreased venous return to the heart. This patient’s clinical presentation of chest pain and shortness of breath in the setting of a recent surgery is more consistent with pulmonary embolism, which results in a ventilation perfusion deficit.
❌ Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock and is due to systemic release of histamine as well as other inflammatory mediators. Unlike obstructive shock, which is associated with cool extremities, anaphylaxis is associated with warm extremities. Additional clues for anaphylactic shock include a history of exposure to an allergen (e.g. bee sting) or presence of a diffuse erythematous rash.
❌ Occlusion of the right coronary artery:
Incorrect: Cardiogenic shock can result from occlusion of the right coronary artery. This type of shock may manifest with right ventricular failure, jugular venous distension, and lethal arrhythmias resulting in compromised cardiac output. Occlusion of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Left ventricular outflow obstruction:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade is a type of obstructive shock that can cause left ventricular outflow obstruction. Clues to this diagnosis include a history of penetrating trauma to the chest, uremia, malignancy, and presence of Beck triad (muffled heart tones, jugular venous distension, and hypotension). An ECG will typically demonstrate “electrical alternans” due to the oscillations of the heart within the pericardium.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old-male presents to the emergency department with increased work of breathing. He was walking to his car when he suddenly became short of breath. Past medical history includes diabetes, hypertension, and a twenty pack year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is, in moderate respiratory distress, and has his left hand held over the sternum. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for bilateral rales without gallops, rubs, or murmurs. Distal extremities are cool to the touch. The patient’s chest x-ray and electrocardiogram are demonstrated below:

Image reproduced from



Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical findings?

choices.text: Occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery
Large thrombus in the pulmonary artery
Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators
Disseminated infection due to a Gram positive cocci

questions.solution:
This patient has respiratory distress, Levine sign (a clenched fist held over the chest commonly associated with anginal chest pain), hemodynamic instability, and cool extremities consistent with “cold shock.”  The differential diagnosis for cold shock includes obstructive shock, cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemic shock. Clues to elucidate the subtype of cold shock rests on clinical history, as well as laboratory, imaging, and electrocardiographic findings. For example, this patient has an ECG demonstrating ST-elevations in the antero-lateral leads and a chest x-ray demonstrating acute pulmonary edema. Together, these clinical findings are consistent with cardiogenic shock, of which the most common cause is acute myocardial infarction.  

Cardiogenic shock refers to inadequate systemic organ perfusion that arises due to cardiac dysfunction. Etiologies include myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, valvular dysfunction, and myocardial contusion. When cardiac myocytes suffer an insult, cardiac output diminishes, and peripheral vascular beds vasoconstrict to increase systemic vascular resistance and divert blood flow to central organs (e.g., heart, kidneys). Due to this shift in vascular flow, patients develop cold peripheral extremities, pallor, and clammy skin. Additionally, the heart's diminished ability to pump blood forward causes pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in acute pulmonary edema and an increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.  

Treatment of cardiogenic shock is dependent on the underlying cause (e.g. revascularization in the case of acute myocardial infarction). In the interim, medications and support devices can be used to assist the patient’s physiology. For instance, inotropic medications and mechanical support devices (e.g. intra-aortic balloon pump) are often utilized.  

Option Analysis

✅ Occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large thrombus in the pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: A large pulmonary embolus is in the differential of obstructive shock and results in hemodynamic compromise due to profound ventilation perfusion mismatch. A large pulmonary embolism can present with a normal chest radiograph, hypoxemia, and an S1Q3T3 pattern on electrocardiogram. However, the condition would not present with ST segment elevation in V1-V5.
❌ Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock. It arises due to systemic release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. Unlike cardiogenic shock, which is associated with cool extremities, anaphylaxis is associated with warm extremities. Additional clues for anaphylactic shock include a history of exposure to an allergen (e.g. bee sting) or presence of a diffuse erythematous rash.  
❌ Disseminated infection due to a Gram positive cocci:
Incorrect: Sepsis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock. The most common cause of septic shock is bacterial pneumonia, which tends to demonstrate a focal consolidation on chest x-ray, as opposed to the diffuse interstitial pattern seen on this patient’s x-ray.  
❌ Lung collapse and tension physiology:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax can cause obstructive shock via compression of mediastinal structures, resulting in impaired venous return and aortic outflow obstruction. This patient has no evidence of pneumothorax on the chest x-ray.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath. Per paramedics, the patient was found down at his assisted living facility with increased work of breathing. Yesterday, the patient was in no acute distress but was noted by nursing staff to be acting “more confused” than usual. The patient’s past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 79/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 89% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is obtunded, ill appearing, and has both suprasternal and intercostal retractions. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


This patient is likely to have which of the following additional clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with increased work of breathing, fever, hypotension, and lactic acidosis. His overall clinical presentation is consistent with septic shock and hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely in the setting of community acquired pneumonia. Septic shock falls under the umbrella of distributive or “warm shock,” which presents with warm, perfused peripheral extremities.  

Distributive shock refers to severe peripheral vasodilation resulting in inadequate perfusion to vital organs. There are three primary causes of distributive shock: sepsis, anaphylaxis, and neurogenic.  Overall, septic shock is the most common cause and refers to a systemic physiologic response to severe infection. Anaphylaxis refers to an extreme systemic response to allergens. Neurogenic shock refers to impaired sympathetic outflow in response to severe neurological trauma.  

Regardless of etiology, the overall clinical and physiologic presentation of distributive shock is similar. Profound peripheral vasodilation results in decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. In response, the heart compensates by increasing cardiac output (via increased heart rate) in an attempt to perfuse vital organs. However, as blood moves faster through capillary beds, the tissues cannot extract the necessary oxygen needed to perform metabolic functions. This phenomenon results in increased anaerobic metabolism, lactic acidosis, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Perfused peripheral extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Delayed capillary refill:
Incorrect: “Cold shock” presents with cool extremities and is most commonly associated with cardiogenic, obstructive, or hypovolemic shock. These etiologies are less likely in this patient who is febrile and has a metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Muffled heart sounds:
Incorrect: Patients with pericardial tamponade, a type of obstructive shock, can present with Beck triad. Beck triad consists of muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension. Clues to this diagnosis include a history of penetrating trauma to the chest, uremia, or malignancy. In contrast, this patient has fever, altered mental status, and metabolic acidosis, which raises greater concerns for infection and sepsis.
❌ Bilateral pulmonary rales:
Incorrect: Cardiogenic shock often presents with pulmonary edema due to decreased cardiac output, increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and subsequent pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with sepsis secondary to community acquired pneumonia, which typically presents with unilateral rales.
❌ Jugular venous distension:
Incorrect: Obstructive shock, which may be due to cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, or pulmonary embolism, falls under the umbrella of “cold shock.” These conditions can present with jugular venous distension due to impaired cardiac outflow.

questions.text:
76-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of increased lower extremity swelling and shortness of breath. The patient has had progressive lower extremity swelling over the past several weeks to the point where she can no longer fit into her normal shoe size. In addition, she can no longer walk half a city block before becoming short of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a deep vein thrombosis after a long flight ten years ago. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty-five years. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg, and O2 is 90% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a loud P2, jugular venous distension, faint bilateral end-expiratory wheezing, and 2+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s lower extremity findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Increased venous hydrostatic pressure and fluid transudation
Decreased venous oncotic pressure and fluid transudation

questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking history presents with peripheral edema, jugular venous distension, and a loud P2 on auscultation. These findings, in the absence of features of left-sided heart failure (e.g., orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, pulmonary edema), favor the diagnosis of cor pulmonale. Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure (RHF) secondary to a pulmonary condition.  

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and other lung diseases can cause pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right ventricular hypertrophy that leads to isolated right heart failure (RHF), or cor pulmonale. In cor pulmonale, the right heart cannot overcome the pressure within the pulmonary circulation, and the backward pressure leads to jugular venous distention, increased portal blood pressure, and peripheral edema. Increased pressure in the portal system can manifest with hepatosplenomegaly, hepatic pulsation, ascites, and, in severe cases, cardiac cirrhosis (i.e., liver cirrhosis due to cardiac causes). In the lower extremities, increased venous hydrostatic pressure overcomes venous oncotic pressures. These changes result in transudation of fluid into the surrounding tissues and subsequent lower extremity edema.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased venous hydrostatic pressure and fluid transudation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased venous oncotic pressure and fluid transudation:
Incorrect: Decreased venous oncotic pressures may also result in lower extremity edema and are characteristic of low protein states, such as cirrhosis or nephrotic syndrome. However, this patient’s history and physical examination do not suggest underlying liver or renal disease states. 
❌ Impaired lymphatic drainage:
Incorrect: Impaired lymphatic drainage, such as in the case of a pelvic or abdominal malignancy, may result in lower extremity edema. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with COPD and cor pulmonale. 
❌ Increased pulmonary venous pressure:
Incorrect: Increased pulmonary venous pressures are associated with left-sided heart failure and pulmonary edema. This patient has an unremarkable chest radiograph and no evidence of pulmonary edema. 
❌ Recurrent deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has a remote history of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), she has evidence of bilateral lower extremity swelling. Bilateral DVTs are incredibly rare and typically occur in the setting of critical illness. Cor pulmonale is a more realistic explanation for her lower extremity findings.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. She is accompanied by her college-roommate, who reports she found the patient wheezing in her room. The patient is unable to provide additional history due to her labored work of breathing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115 min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 90% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has diffuse wheezing throughout the lung fields as well as a diffuse erythematous macular rash over the chest wall. The posterior pharynx is not visualized due to severe lip and tongue swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Systemic release of histamine and bradykinin
Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative diplococci
Bacterial histidine decarboxylase conversion of histidine to histamine

questions.solution:
This patient presents with wheezing, hypotension, airway edema, and a diffuse macular rash consistent with anaphylactic shock. This subtype of distributive shock, or “warm shock,” is due to systemic release of histamine and bradykinin in response to an allergen.  

Anaphylaxis is the most extreme physiologic response to an allergen. Common triggers include peanut allergies or bee stings. It is classified as a type I hypersensitivity reaction, wherein the antigen cross-links performed IgE on presensitized mast cells, resulting in immediate degranulation of histamine and bradykinin. These mediators further trigger an inflammatory response that results in massive vasodilation and soft tissue edema. Edema of the airway causes bronchoconstriction, wheezing, and hypoxemic respiratory failure. Vasodilation subsequently decreases systemic vascular resistance, venous return, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. These changes can result in inadequate tissue perfusion. In response, the body compensates by increasing heart rate and cardiac output.  

Emergent treatment of anaphylaxis involves intramuscular epinephrine, which reverses these pathologic effects via vasoconstriction (by stimulating alpha-1 receptors) and bronchodilation (by stimulating beta-2 receptors). Additional therapy includes systemic corticosteroids and antihistamines.  


Option Analysis

✅ Systemic release of histamine and bradykinin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Infection by the Gram-negative diplococci Neisseria meningitis can lead to septic shock. However, septic shock would not typically present with diffuse wheezing or severe lip and tongue swelling.
❌ C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency:
Incorrect: Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency in C1 esterase and manifests with tongue, lip, and pharyngeal swelling that can progress to hypoxemic failure. Unlike anaphylaxis, this disease does not typically present with a diffuse macular rash.
❌ Paraneoplastic serotonin secretion:
Incorrect: Carcinoid syndrome is due to release of serotonin and vasoactive peptides from a carcinoid tumor. Symptoms include diarrhea, flushing, and wheezing. However, carcinoid syndrome is overall a rare condition and would not account for the patient’s lip and tongue swelling.
❌ Bacterial histidine decarboxylase conversion of histidine to histamine  :
Incorrect: Scombroid toxicity is a common mimicker of anaphylaxis. It is caused by consumption of spoiled dark-meat fish such as tuna, mahi-mahi, mackerel, and bonito. This patient has no history of ingestion of these fish products, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high speed motor vehicle collision. Per paramedics, the patient was the restrained driver and was rear-ended by another vehicle traveling approximately 60 miles per hour. The patient endorses difficulty moving his arms and legs, and endorses pain to the back of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 42/min, respirations are 17/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has a large bruise over the anterior chest wall and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise unremarkable. He is unable to move his arms or legs to command and has absent reflexes below the C6 level. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Inadequate perfusion due to loss of intravascular volume
Compression of mediastinal structures and impaired cardiac outflow
Blunt cardiac injury and excess fluid between the heart and pericardium

questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents after a high speed motor vehicle collision with absent reflexes and paralysis below the C6 level. His vitals demonstrate signs of autonomic dysfunction consistent with neurogenic shock, which is due to impaired sympathetic outflow.  

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive or “warm” shock characterized by inadequate tissue perfusion in the setting of autonomic instability from injury to the central nervous system. Neurogenic shock is most commonly caused by cervical or thoracic spine injuries, but it can also be caused by intracranial hemorrhage, traumatic brain injuries, or inflammatory neuropathies. Most commonly, damage to axons and neural membranes in the intermediolateral nucleus, lateral grey matter, and anterior roots leads to disrupted sympathetic tone and subsequent unopposed parasympathetic outflow. Unopposed parasympathetic tone can cause systemic vasodilation, bradycardia, and bradypnea.  

Ultimately, this manifests with a decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and decreased cardiac output. Hence, it is the only type of shock that does not appropriately respond with reflex tachycardia to hypotension. Patients typically present with flushing, warm extremities, autonomic instability, and decreased or absent reflexes below the level of the injury.


Option Analysis

✅ Impaired sympathetic outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inadequate perfusion due to loss of intravascular volume:
Incorrect: Hypovolemic shock should always be considered in an unstable trauma patient. While intra-abdominal injury and subsequent hemoperitoneum is possible, it is unlikely given his relative bradycardia. Hypovolemic shock presents with compensatory reflex tachycardia due to ongoing volume losses.
❌ Compression of mediastinal structures and impaired cardiac outflow:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax presents with absent unilateral breath sounds, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distension. It is unlikely that this patient, who has a normal cardiopulmonary exam and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, has a tension pneumothorax.
❌ Impaired parasympathetic outflow:
Incorrect: Impaired parasympathetic outflow would result in hypertension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.  Sympathetic, not parasympathetic, outflow is disrupted in neurogenic shock.  
❌ Blunt cardiac injury and excess fluid between the heart and pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade, a form of obstructive shock, presents with Beck triad: muffled heart tones, jugular venous distension, and low blood pressure. In contrast, this patient's cardiopulmonary exam is normal.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. Per emergency medical services, she was found at home surrounded by several empty bottles of vodka. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder, cirrhosis, and heart failure. Temperature is 35.5°C (96.0°F), pulse is 141/min, respirations are 36/min, blood pressure is 75/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, she is unresponsive and dried blood is observed at the mouth and nares. The patient is jaundiced with clammy and cool extremities. Cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise unremarkable. Electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia. Which of the following best describes the physiological parameters of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of alcohol use disorder and cirrhosis presents with altered mental status and signs of hemodynamic instability. On physical exam, the patient has cold and clammy extremities with dried blood at the mouth and nares, an ominous sign for ongoing hemorrhagic shock due to variceal bleeding. Of the physiologic parameters listed, decreased PCWP, decreased CO, increased SVR, and decreased SvO2 are consistent with hypovolemic shock.  

Hypovolemic shock refers to impaired end-organ perfusion due to decreased intravascular volume. There are two types of hypovolemic shock: hemorrhagic and nonhemorrhagic. Hemorrhagic shock occurs due to blood loss from gastrointestinal bleeding, trauma, postpartum complications, surgical complications, or aneurysmal rupture. Non-hemorrhagic shock occurs due to fluid losses including massive diarrhea, vomiting, or severe burns.  

In either case, decreased circulating intravascular volume leads to decreased venous return, decreased cardiac output, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (which is reflective of left atrial pressure). As a compensatory mechanism, heart rate increases and the peripheral vasculature vasoconstricts to shunt blood towards vital organs. Due to this shift in vascular flow, patients develop cold peripheral extremities, pallor, and clammy skin. Additionally, decreased intravascular volume and decreased oxygen carrying capacity decreases the mixed venous oxygen saturation. Treatment includes providing volume replacement: blood in the case of hemorrhage shock and intravenous fluids in the setting of non-hemorrhagic shock.  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with cardiogenic shock, which is also a type of “cold shock” that presents with cool and clammy extremities. Unlike hypovolemic shock, cardiogenic shock demonstrates an increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure due to impaired cardiac contractility. Although this patient has a history of heart failure, the physical exam fails to demonstrate evidence of new murmur or pulmonary edema, making cardiogenic shock less likely.
❌ :
Incorrect: These physiologic parameters reflect shock that has been treated with intravenous fluids, blood products, or inotropic medications. This patient has not yet received any treatment.
❌ :
Incorrect: Distributive shock refers to shock from anaphylaxis or sepsis. Unlike hypovolemic shock, distributive shock is a type of “warm shock” (e.g. warm extremities) and presents with a large decrease in systemic vascular resistance due to release of inflammatory mediators.
❌ :
Incorrect: Neurogenic shock falls under the category of “warm shock” and presents clinically after severe head or spinal cord trauma or intracerebral hemorrhage. Autonomic instability ensues, resulting in decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, cardiac output, and systemic vascular resistance.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. She was found down by her neighbors, who immediately called EMS. Medical history is notable for multiple myeloma, for which she is currently undergoing treatment. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 137/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 89% on room air. Physical exam reveals a cachectic, ill-appearing woman who is moaning and unable to provide further history. She has bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness to palpation as well as warm and perfused peripheral extremities. Subsequent blood cultures grow gram-negative rods. Which of the following is the most likely trigger of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, fever, hypotension, and growth of a gram-negative rod on blood culture. This clinical presentation is consistent with septic shock in the setting of pyelonephritis. Of the triggers listed above, lipid A, a component of gram-negative bacteria, is responsible for the systemic inflammatory response mediating sepsis.  

Lipid A is a heat-stable endotoxin and component of the lipopolysaccharide cell wall in gram-negative bacteria. When gram-negative bacteria are lysed by the immune system, lipid A is released into the bloodstream, inducing macrophages to release TNF, IL-1, and IL-6. These inflammatory cytokines activate and injure the vascular endothelium, leading to nitric oxide release and systemic vasodilation. They also promote tissue factor (thromboplastin) expression, triggering the extrinsic coagulation cascade and potentially resulting in disseminated intravascular coagulation. 

Clinically, septic shock manifests with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. The heart compensates by increasing cardiac output, producing a high flow state wherein tissues cannot properly extract circulating oxygen. This results in increased anaerobic metabolism, lactic acidosis, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation.  

If untreated, septic shock portends a high mortality rate due to the body’s inability to perfuse vital organs. Septic shock can result in multi-organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and thrombosis. Treatment involves fluid resuscitation, broad spectrum antibiotics, and vasopressors for hemodynamic support.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lipid A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Histamine and bradykinin:
Incorrect: The primary mediators of anaphylactic shock, which is a subtype of “warm” or distributive shock, are histamine and bradykinin. Triggers for anaphylactic shock include bee stings or other allergens such as peanuts. In contrast, this patient has fever, bilateral costovertebral tenderness, and a positive blood culture, which raises more concerns for septic shock secondary to a urinary tract infection.
❌ Mutation in factor V:
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden is a hereditary clotting disorder that promotes the formation of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, which can lead to obstructive shock. Although this patient is at risk for venous thromboembolism given the history of malignancy, this clinical presentation is more consistent with septic shock.
❌ Thromboplastin:
Incorrect: Tissue thromboplastin is commonly activated in the setting of severe sepsis and can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). While this patient has features of septic shock, she does not display features of DIC, such as oozing from IV sites or ecchymosis.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a protein produced by Streptococcus pyogenes, a gram-positive coccus. This protein degrades cell membranes and lyses red blood cells RBCs. While Streptococcus pyogenes can induce septic shock, this exotoxin is not implicated in its pathogenesis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office due to ankle swelling and abdominal discomfort for the past three weeks. He also has shortness of breath and wheezing on exertion, but he denies orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Patient history is significant for a 50 pack-year smoking history, and he drinks approximately 7-8 units of alcohol per week. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9° F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities, tenderness of the right upper quadrant, and prominent jugular veins. Cardiac examination shows a loud pulmonic component of S2 (P2) on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking history is presenting with peripheral edema, hepatic congestion, jugular venous distension, as well as a loud P2 on auscultation. These characteristics, in the absence of features of left sided heart failure (e.g., orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) all favor the diagnosis of cor pulmonale. Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure (RHF) secondary to a pulmonary condition. For example, this patient most likely has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to chronic smoking, which is contributing to his dyspnea on exertion. COPD causes hypoxia, leading to vasoconstriction in the pulmonary vasculature. This elevation in pulmonary arterial pressure causes a backup of pressure into the right ventricle that eventually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.  The loud P2 heard on cardiac auscultation reflects the increased closing pressure of the valve against pulmonary hypertension secondary to lung disease. As the condition progresses, it can lead to isolated RHF. It is important to note that the most common cause of RHF is left heart failure (LHF).    Since the right side of the heart cannot overcome the pressure in the pulmonary circulation, backward pressure leads to jugular venous distention, increased portal blood pressure, and peripheral edema. Increased pressure in the portal system presents with hepatosplenomegaly, hepatic pulsation, ascites and, in severe cases, cardiac cirrhosis (i.e., liver cirrhosis due to cardiac causes). On gross morphology, the congested liver is called a nutmeg liver due to congested centrilobular areas surrounded by paler, non-congested parenchyma.  


It is important to distinguish RHF and LHF based on the causes, history, clinical examination, and diagnostic investigations:  




Option Analysis

❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Prolonged hypertension can result in left ventricular concentric hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction (the heart can not fill properly) due to reduced compliance. This can eventually lead to left-sided heart failure. Symptoms of left-sided heart failure include dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea due to pulmonary edema. This patient has clinical features of right-sided heart failure. Although this patient has dyspnea, this is most likely due to a primary lung condition, such as COPD, secondary to smoking.  
❌ Chronic alcohol use:
Incorrect: Chronic alcohol use is a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy. This results in eccentric hypertrophy of the heart and systolic dysfunction (the heart can not pump blood out), which leads to left-sided heart failure. This diagnosis is unlikely as the patient is presenting with right-sided heart failure. In addition, he is drinking a moderate level, and a S3 (sign of volume overload) would be expected as opposed to a loud P2 on auscultation.
✅ Cor pulmonale:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is an autosomal dominant condition most commonly caused by a mutation in genes which encode sarcomeric proteins. This mutation leads to asymmetric septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve which results in outlet obstruction. Presentation is variable and may include dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, palpitations, syncope, sudden cardiac death. This condition usually affects younger athletes. 
❌ Tuberculosis   :
Incorrect: Tuberculosis is a cause of constrictive pericarditis, which can eventually lead to diastolic dysfunction and right heart failure. Constrictive pericarditis can present with signs of right heart side failure as seen in this patient. However, other signs of tuberculosis would also be expected (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, fever, and night sweats).   
❌ Mitral insufficiency:
Incorrect: Mitral insufficiency can cause left sided failure. However, mitral insufficiency (i.e. regurgitation) will present with a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, not a loud P2.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of shortness of breath. Over the past several weeks, the patient has been using three to four pillows to prop herself up to sleep at night. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and myocardial infarction with stent placement. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 148/82 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional low frequency heart sound heard just after S2. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this cardiac finding?

choices.text: Age-related calcification of the aortic valve

questions.solution:
This patient presents with cardiac auscultatory findings characteristic of an S3 or ventricular gallop. The finding is most commonly associated with heart failure and increased ventricular filling pressures.   

The third heart sound (S3) is clinically characterized as a low-frequency, brief vibration occurring in early diastole at the end of the rapid diastolic filling period of the right or left ventricle. In other words, this sound is heard immediately after the normal two "lub-dub" heart sounds (S1 and S2). The sound itself occurs as blood oscillates back and forth between the walls of dilated, compliant ventricles and is observed in patients with heart failure. This heart sound is best heard over the cardiac apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased ventricular filling pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventricular non-compliance :
Incorrect: The S4 gallop, characterized by an extra heart sound heard in late diastole, occurs just after atrial contraction and immediately before the systolic S1 heart sound. This heart sound is reflective of an abnormally stiff or hypertrophic ventricle. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Untreated Streptococcal throat infection:
Incorrect: Rheumatic heart disease typically results in the development of mitral stenosis. This valvular pathology is characterized by an opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Age-related calcification of the aortic valve:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis is most commonly due to age-related calcification of the aortic valve and is characterized by a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur and soft S2 heart sound. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Ventricular septal defect :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defects are characterized by holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmurs. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty sleeping. The patient has experienced progressive shortness of breath over the past several weeks to the point where he can no longer walk to the bathroom without becoming winded. He has woken up multiple times per night with shortness of breath and has been propping himself up with several pillows to sleep. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, a 25-pack-year smoking history, and heart failure (ejection fraction 14%). He is adherent to prescribed medications, including furosemide. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 101/82 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional heart sound heard just after S2, jugular venous distension, diffuse rales on auscultation of the lungs, and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased brain and atrial natriuretic peptide levels

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of left ventricular dysfunction (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, pulmonary edema), right ventricular failure (e.g., jugular venous distention, lower extremity edema), and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.   

In patients with decompensated heart failure, neuroendocrine mechanisms contribute to a vicious cycle in an attempt to restore hemodynamics. Diminished cardiac output fails to perfuse vital organs like the kidneys, prompting activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Activation of RAAS promotes increased levels of angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, and aldosterone, which increases sodium and water retention. Together, these two sequelae of the RAAS system also lead to increased afterload. Concurrently, the diminished cardiac output manifests with activation of the sympathetic nervous system, which further increases arteriolar tone and afterload.  

Over time, the compensatory mechanisms of the heart (e.g. secretion of the diuretic and vasodilatory peptides BNP/ANP) fail to compensate for this overactivation of the sympathetic nervous and RAAS systems, thus lending towards a vicious cycle of increasing afterload, strain on the left ventricle, and decompensated heart failure.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased levels of angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased renal perfusion:
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, renal perfusion is observed in patients with decompensated heart failure. Decreased renal perfusion results in increased activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which further worsens the symptoms of heart failure.    
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure. In contrast, this patient presents with clinical findings of left ventricular dysfunction. 
❌ Increased stroke volume :
Incorrect: Stroke volume may slightly increase in early heart failure as a compensatory mechanism. However, later in the disease, stroke volume becomes profoundly diminished. 
❌ Decreased brain and atrial natriuretic peptide levels:
Incorrect: Both brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) are protein molecules secreted by the atria and ventricles in response to stretch. These molecules serve to counteract the negative effects of heart failure by promoting diuresis and vasodilation. Both of these peptides are elevated in patients with decompensated heart failure.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to increasing shortness of breath over the past several weeks. The patient can no longer climb a flight of stairs or walk one city block without becoming short of breath. Past medical history includes diabetes and hypertension. The patient has not seen a physician in years and is currently not on any medications. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 201/97 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates bibasilar rales and a palpable S4 heart sound. Bedside point of care ultrasound demonstrates left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following best describes the likely physiologic parameters regarding this patient’s left ventricular cardiac function?
questions.solution:
This patient with long-standing, untreated hypertension presents with clinical features of heart failure. Specifically, the presence of an S4 gallop and evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy on ultrasound suggest left ventricular diastolic dysfunction.  

Diastolic heart failure is most commonly due to cardiac hypertrophy from long-standing, untreated hypertension. Diastolic heart failure presents with the same clinical features as systolic heart failure. Echocardiographic findings generally demonstrate a preserved EF and a normal EDV. Patients with diastolic heart failure will also have decreased compliance (increased end diastolic pressure) due to stiff ventricular walls. Other etiologies of diastolic heart failure include infiltrative diseases, such as amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, and post-radiation fibrosis.    


In contrast, systolic heart failure is most commonly due to ischemia or myocardial infarction, which causes decreased cardiac contractility that leads to systolic dysfunction. Other causes of systolic heart failure include etiologies of dilated cardiomyopathy, such as chronic alcohol use, coxsackie B virus infection, chronic cocaine use, and Chagas disease. The inability of the heart to effectively pump blood forward through the circulation results in clinical features of left-sided heart failure, such as pulmonary edema (e.g., bibasilar crackles, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) and an S3 heart sound (ventricular gallop). Systolic heart failure often progresses to right-sided heart failure, resulting in jugular venous distention (JVD), pitting edema, and hepatic congestion. Echocardiography in systolic heart failure typically shows an increased end diastolic volume (EDV), decreased contractility (or wall motion abnormalities), and reduced ejection fraction (EF).  

Option Analysis

✅  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  ↓  ↑ ↑:
Incorrect: These findings are indicative of systolic heart failure, not diastolic heart failure. 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  ↑↑ :
Incorrect: These findings are indicative of a recovered ejection fraction or impending heart failure (compensatory). 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings describe healthy cardiac function without evidence of underlying pathology. This patient has multiple clinical features that suggest underlying diastolic heart failure. 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance ↓ ↑ Normal :
Incorrect: These findings may be present in cases of neurogenic shock, wherein decreased sympathetic tone manifests with a decrease in ejection fraction and subsequent increase in EDV.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath, which began four hours ago. The patient also has swelling of the bilateral lower extremities. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. At arrival, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 145/87 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Physical examination reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles and pitting edema in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered and reveals the findings below. Laboratory testing reveals a sodium level of 135 mEq/L and potassium of 5.3 mEq/L. Concurrent administration of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath, peripheral edema, and increased lung shadowing on the x-ray in the setting of congestive heart disease. He most likely has pulmonary edema. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia. To avoid exacerbating the electrolyte abnormality or triggering an arrhythmia, patients with hyperkalemia should avoid taking potassium-sparing diuretics.

Potassium-sparing diuretics are used in the treatment of hypertension and edematous states, such as pulmonary edema and abdominal ascites. This is because potassium-sparing diuretics increase sodium and water loss via urine, which helps decrease plasma volume, cardiac output, and extracellular fluid volume. In addition, potassium-sparing diuretics that act as aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in treating conditions associated with hyperaldosteronism (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal hyperplasia).

Finally, spironolactone and amiloride can bind to androgen receptors and prevent testosterone from binding. These medications help blunt the effects of testosterone in the body and can be used to manage conditions such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Of note, spironolactone has stronger antiandrogenic properties and is used more commonly than amiloride to treat PCOS.

Side effects on these medications include hyperkalemia (due to reduced potassium excretion) and metabolic acidosis (due to reduced potassium excretion). In addition, spironolactone can cause gynecomastia as a side effect.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Triamterene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: This patient has pulmonary and peripheral edema, likely due to congestive heart failure exacerbation. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia and medications that increase serum potassium levels should be used with caution, as they may exacerbate hyperkalemia and cause arrhythmias. However, metformin does not typically increase serum potassium levels.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hypokalemia as a side effect. As a result, it can be administered safely to this patient, who has hyperkalemia.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive that causes vasodilation. Side effects include headache, reflex tachycardia, and lupus-like syndrome. However, it does not exacerbate hyperkalemia. Hence, hydralazine can be safely administered to this patient.  
❌ Glyburide:
Incorrect: Glyburide is a medication that increases endogenous insulin release. Side effects include disulfiram-like reactions, hypoglycemia, and weight gain. However, glyburide would not typically cause hyperkalemia and would not exacerbate this patient’s electrolyte abnormality.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and palpitations for 2 hours. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, nonischemic cardiomyopathy, and hypertension. Current medications include furosemide, metoprolol, lisinopril, and digoxin. The patient’s ejection fraction on transthoracic echocardiography a month ago was 40%. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular rhythm and nonspecific T wave changes. The patient is started on apixaban and amiodarone. His symptoms improved during the hospital stay, and he was discharged home on day three, with these new medications added to his regimen. He returns to the emergency department a week later with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s current presentation with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain suggests digoxin toxicity, most likely due to the addition of amiodarone to the patient’s medication regimen.

Acute toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, hyperkalemia, and cardiac arrhythmias (sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation). In contrast, chronic toxicity presents with less profound gastrointestinal symptoms and more significant neurological (e.g., lethargy, fatigue, and confusion) and visual (e.g., changes in color vision and scotomas) symptoms.

Amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, or propafenone (when coadministered with digoxin) can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity by reducing its renal excretion (competing for or inhibiting P-glycoprotein) or by displacement of digoxin from tissue binding sites. This leads to increased serum levels in a patient who has previously been on a stable digoxin regimen. It is recommended to decrease the dose of digoxin by 20-50% when initiating therapy with any of these drugs.

Other factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Hypokalemia which can increase digoxin binding at the K+-binding site on Na+/K+ ATPase
  • Hypomagnesemia (which leads to hypokalemia)
  • Renal failure (decreased digoxin clearance)
 


Option Analysis

❌ Erosive gastritis:
Incorrect: Erosive gastritis can present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. This patient's presentation with generalized fatigue in a possible drug interaction makes this unlikely.  
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis usually presents with nausea, vomiting, and epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back in predisposing factors (e.g., excessive alcohol use and gallstones). This patient’s presentation is not typical of pancreatitis.  
✅ Drug interaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Apixaban toxicity:
Incorrect: Apixaban is an anticoagulant, and its toxicity can present with bleeding gums, epistaxis, hematuria, melena, or hematochezia, none of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Heart failure exacerbation:
Incorrect: Heart failure exacerbation usually presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, cough, early satiety, weight gain, and increasing abdominal girth. It is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive difficulty breathing, which has been ongoing for the last 2 days. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure with an ejection fraction of 31%. The patient does not take his medications and consumes salty foods. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows a man with labored breathing and bilateral lower extremity edema. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral crackles. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous furosemide. This medication acts on which of the following regions of the nephron?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute decompensated heart failure. The mainstay of management involves intravenous diuresis, typically with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.        

In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide, bumetanide, torsemide) bind and inhibit the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter. As a result, sodium, potassium, and chloride cannot be reabsorbed into the bloodstream and get excreted out with the urine. Other ions that depend on sodium reabsorption, such as calcium and magnesium, are excreted as well. These changes ultimately lead to decreased water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.        

Major indications for loop diuretics include hypertension and edematous states (e.g., heart failure, ascites, acute pulmonary edema). Moreover, these medications can also be used to correct certain electrolyte imbalances such as hypercalcemia and hyperkalemia. Lastly, loop diuretics are also effective in treating acute bromide, fluoride, or iodide intoxications because these substances are also reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb.  



Option Analysis

❌ Region A:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, thereby blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. It is used to relieve intracranial pressure in idiopathic intracranial hypertension and intraocular pressure in glaucoma. Furosemide, in contrast, acts on a different part of the nephron. 
❌ Region B:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle carries fluid from the proximal tubule to the ascending loop of Henle. It allows reabsorption of water into the interstitial fluids to produce concentrated urine. However, loop diuretics such as furosemide act on a different part of the nephron. 
✅ Region C:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Region D:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) act on the early distal tubule, where they inhibit Na+/Cl- contransporters. 
❌ Region E:
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on the collecting tubules. Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, do not act here.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and orthopnea. Past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and myocardial infarction, which occurred 9 months ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure and pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral crackles. The patient is treated with a medication that results in brisk diuresis and subsequent symptomatic improvement. The patient is sent home on this medication. Three weeks later, laboratory analysis revealed reduced serum calcium and magnesium levels. The diuretic prescribed to this patient predominantly acts on which of the following nephron segments?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of acute decompensated heart failure. The mainstay of management is intravenous diuresis, typically with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.        

Loop diuretics act on the ascending limb of the loop of Henle by binding and inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter. Inhibition of sodium chloride reabsorption also inhibits the back leak of potassium into the tubule and prevents the generation of a positive intraluminal potential within the ascending loop of Henle. As a result, there is a decreased electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increased loss of magnesium and calcium via urine. Due to these effects, loop diuretics can cause hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia.    

Option Analysis

❌ Proximal tubule:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, thereby blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. Acetazolamide may cause metabolic acidosis, but not hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. 
❌ Descending loop of Henle:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle is not a common site of action for diuretics. 
✅ Thick ascending loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Distal tubule:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide) act on the early distal tubule and inhibit NaCl reabsorption. While thiazide diuretics may cause hypomagnesemia, they do not typically cause hypocalcemia. 
❌ Cortical collecting duct :
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on collecting duct systems. However, these medications are not typically associated with hypocalcemia or hypomagnesemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a two-day history of shortness of breath and confusion. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (last estimated to be 20%). The patient reports infrequent follow-up visits and medication nonadherence. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 73/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool extremities, jugular venous distention, and diffuse crackles in the lungs. Treatment with intravenous agents is started. The agents specifically decrease the rate of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) degradation via the inhibition of an enzyme. Which of the following is an example of the drug used in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with worsening dyspnea, confusion, bibasilar crackles, and JVD is consistent with cardiogenic shock secondary to heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). An intravenous milrinone (a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor) infusion is started in this patient to improve cardiac contractility.

PDE-3 inhibitors, such as milrinone and enoximone, decrease the rate of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) degradation. The ensuing increase in cyclic AMP concentration leads to enhanced calcium influx into the cell, a rise in cell calcium concentration, and increased contractility. These drugs also cause systemic arterial and venous dilation, viral causes of vascular PDE. Milrinone is used as an inotropic agent in acute heart failure. It should not be used in chronic heart failure because it increases morbidity and mortality. Side effects include arrhythmias and hypotension due to significant vasodilation.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Milrinone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dobutamine:
Incorrect: Dobutamine is a highly selective beta-agonist for beta-1 receptors. It is coupled to Gs protein, which stimulates adenylate cyclase. This increases the production of cAMP (rather than decreasing its degradation) in the target cells leading to an increase in calcium influx into the cells and the force of cardiac muscle contraction (positive inotropy and chronotropy).  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin acts by direct inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase, indirectly inhibiting Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, leading to increased calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This calcium increases cardiac contractility (positive inotropy) when this calcium is released. It does not affect AMP degradation, an effect similar to that of milrinone.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: ACE inhibitors (ACEI) such as captopril, enalapril, or lisinopril, inhibit the action of ACE and prevent the formation of angiotensin II and aldosterone and results in an increase in endogenous vasodilators of the kinin family. It is indicated in hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy.  
❌ Dapagliflozin:
Incorrect: Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that reduces blood glucose by increasing urinary glucose excretion and is used to reduce the risk of progression of diabetic kidney disease. It is a treatment option for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath. He states that these symptoms have been gradually worsening, but recently, he woke up in the middle of the night suddenly feeling short of breath. He sleeps in a recliner because he gets short of breath while lying flat. Past medical history of obesity and hypertension, which is currently not treated. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 187/108 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% in room air. Physical examination shows mild jugular venous distention. Mild bibasilar crackles are noted on chest auscultation. Which of the following substances will be produced in the small pulmonary vessels in response to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with cough and shortness of breath, jugular venous distension, and bibasilar crackles are suggestive of decompensated heart failure. The decrease in cardiac output leads to renal hypoperfusion and the subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).    

When blood pressure is low, blood flow to the kidneys decreases. The kidneys respond by secreting renin into the bloodstream. Renin is a proteolytic enzyme that breaks down a protein made in the liver called angiotensinogen, and this gives rise to angiotensin I. When angiotensin I reaches the lungs, angiotensin I is converted into angiotensin II by an enzyme called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the pulmonary vessels. Angiotensin II binds to receptors in vascular smooth muscle and causes them to constrict, which increases the blood pressure. Finally, angiotensin II also stimulates the release of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys, which also increases water reabsorption. This results in increased blood volume, which also increases blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌ Renin:
Incorrect: Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney in response to decreased cardiac output leading to renal hypoperfusion.  
❌ Angiotensin I:
Incorrect: Angiotensinogen is converted to angiotensin I in the systemic circulation via the action of renin.   
✅ Angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aldosterone:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II acts on the adrenal glands to stimulate the production and release of aldosterone, which acts on the collecting duct of the nephron to retain sodium and water.  
❌ Prostaglandin E1:
Incorrect: Prostaglandins are produced by endothelial cells, macrophages, and mast cells. It acts on the afferent arterioles of the nephron to cause vasodilation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with no significant past medical history develops a bowel perforation and subsequently undergoes surgical repair. He develops significant hypotension while under general anesthesia. Intraoperative blood loss is minimal. A large dose of epinephrine is administered, which temporarily raises the patient's blood pressure. Several subsequent doses of epinephrine are administered and cause a much weaker response. Which of the following mechanisms is likely contributing to the decreased effects of this medication?

choices.text: Increased activity of intracellular arrestin proteins
Increased production of secondary messenger molecules

questions.solution:
Desensitization and tolerance are important concepts in pharmacodynamics and refers to a decreased effect of a drug (e.g. alcohol, heroin) or medication over time following subsequent doses. Over time, as an agonist binds to its cellular receptor, it may lose its ability to produce a robust response within cells via secondary messengers. Desensitization (also called tachyphylaxis) generally occurs rapidly and can occur after the first dose of a medication. On the other hand, tolerance occurs always after repeated doses and may take weeks or months. In this patient, he is likely experiencing desensitization (tachyphylaxis) to epinephrine, so repeated doses exert a weaker effect than the original dose.

Desensitization and tolerance can occur via many mechanisms, with several of the most common mechanisms outlined below:

  1. Downregulation of receptor expression. For example, chronic opioid use results in downregulating the number of receptors available to bind the opioid or may increase the degradation or sequestration of receptors. This results in stronger doses of opioids needed to produce the same effect.
  2. Uncoupling of receptors to secondary messengers. This is often mediated by proteins called arrestins, which bind to G-protein-coupled receptors to prevent interaction with secondary messengers. They can also tag these receptors for endocytosis. This is common in desensitization (tachyphylaxis).
  3. Exhaustion of intracellular intermediary molecules. This can occur with drugs such as amphetamines, which eventually leads to the depletion of secondary messengers within cells.
  4. Increased breakdown of agonists. For example, this can occur with chronic alcohol use, as “tolerance” increases with repeated chronic use due to more rapid degradation of ethanol.
  5. Physiologic adaptation in the body. For example, this can occur with thiazide diuretics due to increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased activity of intracellular arrestin proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Increased number of extracellular receptors:
Incorrect: If more extracellular receptors were available, there would be more binding to the agonist (medication), making it more likely to maintain or increase a cellular response (i.e. drug effect).  
❌ Increased production of secondary messenger molecules:
Incorrect: Since medications/drugs work by binding to a cellular receptor and causing effects via secondary messengers, an increase in secondary messengers is more likely to maintain or increase a cellular response (i.e. drug effect).
